I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
partial  credit  guarantee  (PCG)  of  up  to  $33.43  million  issued  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB)  in  favor  of  the  Islamic  Development  Bank  (IDB)  in  respect  of  IDB’s  financing  of 
Foundation  Wind  Energy  I  Limited  for  the  Foundation  Wind  Energy  I  Project  in  Pakistan  and 
(ii) a  proposed  PCG  of up  to  $33.18 million  issued  by  ADB  in  favor  of  IDB  in  respect  of  IDB’s 
financing  of  Foundation  Wind  Energy  II  Limited  for  the  Foundation  Wind  Energy  II  Project  in 
Pakistan.  
 

II. 

THE PROJECTS 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 

2. 
Project  identification.  As  in  many  developing  countries,  an  energy  deficit  is  a  major 
constraint on efficient economic growth in Pakistan. To ensure a sustainable supply of energy, 
the  Government  of  Pakistan  launched  a  number  of  initiatives  to  promote  private  sector 
participation in the country's energy infrastructure, including the power sector. As part of these 
efforts,  a  number  of  power  policies  were  introduced,  such  as  the  Power  Policy,  2002  and  the 
Renewable Energy Policy, 2006. As of 30 September 2011, almost 40% of the country’s power 
capacity was owned and operated by international and national private sector investors. 
 
3. 
 
The sponsors initiated discussions with ADB to raise debt and equity financing for both 
4. 
projects,  attracted  by  ADB’s  strong  presence  and  track  record  in  Pakistan’s  power  sector;  it’s 
support  for  Zorlu  Enerji,  the  first  wind  project  in  Pakistan;1 and  its  strong  and  longstanding 
relationship with  the  Fauji  Foundation. The  project team  introduced  the  sponsors to the  ADB–
IDB funded Islamic Infrastructure Fund to provide the balance of equity for the two transactions. 
At the same time ADB initiated cofinancing discussions with IDB for the projects. ADB and IDB 
have a close working relationship and have recently worked together on several transactions in 
Pakistan:  New  Bong  Escape  Hydropower, 2  Uch-II  Power, 3  and  Patrind  Hydropower. 4  The 
presence  of  ADB  in  the  transactions  helped  catalyze  local  currency  debt,  which  is  being 
arranged by National Bank of Pakistan.  
 
5. 
The sponsors requested that all financing for the two projects be obtained in compliance 
with Islamic Shariah principles. IDB and local banks are raising financing on this basis. To meet 
the needs of the client, ADB will make innovative use of PCGs, allowing the project companies 
to raise all financing in line with Shariah. In the event the PCG structure is implemented, this will 
be  the  first  time  ADB  participates  in  a  debt  financing  that  is  entirely  compliant  with  Shariah.  
Shariah  financing,  though  new  to  ADB,  is  well  established  in  the  market  and  has  seen 
tremendous growth in recent years. In addition, ADB is familiar with Shariah structure as it has 
cofinanced several transactions in which IDB has provided a Shariah tranche alongside ADB’s

6. 
Project  design. The  two  projects  are  located  in the Gharo  wind  corridor  54 kilometers 
southeast of Karachi, Pakistan’s industrial and commercial hub. The two project sites are only 6 
kilometers  apart  and  are  being  simultaneously  developed  to  benefit  from  economies  of  scale. 
The  two  projects  will  have  the  same  set  of  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction  (EPC) 
contractors,  financiers,  and  technical  and  legal  advisors  but  are  legally,  economically,  and 
contractually  distinct  and  will  not  rely  on  each  other’s  cash  flows.  ADB  will  participate  in  two 
distinct, stand-alone project financings 
 
7. 
The two projects will encompass engineering, design, procurement, construction, turbine 
erection, grid tie-in, commissioning, and operation and maintenance (O&M) for two 50 MW wind 
power plants. The projects will be constructed under a date-certain, lump-sum, fixed-price EPC 
contract. Power evacuation from both projects to the national grid will be through a 132-kilovolt 
line to be built and operated by the National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC), the 
national grid operator. Power offtake arrangements will be through a 20-year take-or-pay energy 
purchase  agreement  (EPA)  signed  by  each  project  company  and  NTDC  through  its  Central 
Power Purchasing Agency. The government will guarantee NTDC’s obligations under the EPA 
as part of its obligations under a 20-year implementation agreement.  
 
8. 
 
B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

 CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 

9. 
Impact. The successful development of the projects will help alleviate Pakistan’s severe 
power  shortage,  which  cramps  the  country’s  economic  growth  and  efforts  to  reduce  poverty. 
The  successful  implementation  of the  projects  will foster  confidence  among  potential  investors 
and  lenders  and  promote  further  private  sector  investment  in  renewable  energy  and  power  in 
Pakistan.  
 
10. 
Outcome. The  outcome  of the  projects  is  the  production of  lower-cost,  carbon-efficient 
power from wind energy. FWE I will generate annually 143.2 gigawatts (GWh) and FWE II will 
generate  annually  143.7  GWh  of  competitively  priced,  low-carbon  power  for  Pakistan’s 
consumers. The capacity  factor  of  FWE I  is  expected  to be  32.7%  and of  FWE II  32.8%. The 
projects  will  incrementally  increase  access  to  energy  for  households,  business,  and  industry. 
The projected levelized tariff for FWE I and II is expected to be $0.15 per kilowatt-hour (kWh), 
which  compares  favorably  with  $0.19–0.23  per  kWh,  the  incremental  cost  of  furnace  oil  or 
diesel-based  power  generation.  The  projects  will  avoid  greenhouse  gas  emissions  equal  to 
68,000 tons of carbon dioxide per year for FWE I and 68,250 tons for FWE II and support the 
government’s  target  of  generating  6%  of  power  from  renewable  energy  sources  by  2030.  By 
efficiently  using  an  energy  resource  that  is  domestic,  idle,  and  renewable,  the  projects  will 
contribute to Pakistan’s energy security and the diversification of its skewed power mix,  which 
currently  relies  heavily  on  expensive  oil  imports.  Fossil  fuels  have  experienced  severe  price 
escalation and volatility in recent years, which has undermined the financial health of the power 
sector  and  economy  in  general.  Diversification  using  indigenous  and  renewable  sources  of 
power  is  an  important  avenue  towards  addressing  the  long-term  financial  health  of  the  power

11. 
Outputs. The outputs will be the installing and commissioning of two 50 MW wind power 
projects.  The  projects  will  create  local  employment  in  southern  Sindh,  one  of  the  poorest 
regions in Pakistan.  
  
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

Consistency  with  Strategy  2020.  The  projects  are  consistent  with  Strategy  2020, 6 
12. 
which  emphasizes  infrastructure  investment to achieve  rapid but  sustainable economic growth 
and to connect the poor to markets and improve their access to basic productive assets as part 
of  ADB’s  support  for  achieving  inclusive  growth.  The  projects  will  (i)  promote  private  sector 
development  and  catalyze  private  sector  operations  and  (ii)  leverage  partnerships  through 
cofinancing with IDB, which are among the five drivers of change addressed by Strategy 2020.  
 
13. 
Consistency  with  country  strategy.  ADB’s  support  for  the  projects  is  in  line  with  its 
country  partnership  strategy  for  Pakistan,  2009–2013, 7  which  emphasizes  energy  sector 
development,  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  development,  and  the  expansion  of 
ADB’s private sector operations in the energy sector. Both projects are logical continuations of 
ADB’s  development  and  reform  efforts  in  Pakistan’s  energy  sector,  which  promote  a  well-
regulated, market-oriented power industry.  
 
14. 
Consistency with energy policy. The projects promote renewable energy, which is one 
of the three pillars of ADB’s Energy Policy.8 ADB finances renewable energy projects to facilitate 
the  wider  deployment  of  clean  energy  technologies  and  has  set  the  target  of  promoting  clean 
energy investments of more than $1 billion annually, to which ADB support to the projects will 
contribute. The projects will foster reduced fossil fuel use and contribute to the country’s energy 
security by using indigenous wind resources.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
D. 

Projected Economic Performance 

15. 
The projects are economically sustainable, as the economic internal rates of return are 
12.42%  for  FWE  I  and  12.41%  for  FWE  II,  higher  than  the  social  discount  rate  of  10%. 9 
Sensitivity analysis shows the projects are economically viable under adverse scenarios. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

16. 
ADB’s assistance will be in the form of  a PCG of up to $33.43 million for FWE I and a 
PCG  of  up  to  $33.18  million  for  FWE  II  issued  by  ADB.  in  favor  of  IDB.  IDB  will  finance  the 
projects  based  on  ijarah  (a  Shariah-compliant  financing  structure  similar  to  lease  financing).

 4 

 

 

Broadly, under ijarah IDB will advance money to each project company during construction for 
developing  and  procuring  certain  project  assets.  During  operations,  each project  company  will 
pay rent to IDB for the use of those assets, the amount to be equivalent to principal plus interest 
payments  under  a  conventional  loan.  ADB’s  PCG  will  cover  any  nonpayment  by  the  project 
company  to  IDB,  which  includes  initial  disbursements  by  IDB,  plus  rental  payments  and  other 
additional associated costs. ADB’s PCG will cover half of the amount of IDB’s financing to the 
project company. On the balance amount, IDB will take full project risk. Both PCGs will have a 
tenor of 12 years and match the tenor of IDB financing. 
 
17. 
In  the  event  the  PCG  structure  cannot  be  implemented  due  to  lack  of  regulatory 
approvals,  lack  of  final  legal  documentation  acceptable  to  ADB,  or  other  reasons,  ADB’s 
assistance will be in the form of a direct loan of up to $33.43 million for FWE I and a direct loan 
of up to $33.18 million for FWE II. Both loans will have a tenor of 12 years with a grace period of 
2 years. The proceeds of the PCG-guaranteed financing or the loans will fund the construction 
and  development  of  the  two  projects.  ADB’s  assistance  to  both  projects  will  be  from  ADB’s 
ordinary  capital  resources  without  government  guarantee.  ADB’s  PCGs  will  carry  guarantee 
fees, and ADB’s loans will carry interest and other fees and terms to be  determined by ADB’s 
investment committee.  
 
B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

18. 

ADB assistance adds value in the following ways:  
(i) 

(ii)

(iv) 

ADB  provides  financing  to  critical  assets  in  a  sector  that  does  not  readily  have 
access to long-term funding under the present financial and country environment. 
ADB’s  assistance  to  the  projects  will  increase  the  supply  of  energy,  stem  a 
growing  power  deficit  that  has  seriously  constrained  economic  growth,  and 
expand access to energy for households, business, and industry. 
The  presence  of  ADB  reassures  the  sponsors  that  government  entities  will 
continue to support the projects throughout their life. ADB was the first financial 
institution  that  the  sponsors  approached  to  finance  the  projects  because  of  its 
track record in the country and the sector and the value the sponsors placed on 
the  risk-mitigation  and  financial-catalyst  role  that  ADB  has  played  in  supporting 
private sector projects in Pakistan. 
As part of its public sector program, ADB has a strong energy focus in Pakistan. 
Its  work  on  reform  and  regulations  has  supported  the  creation  of  an  enabling 
environment for  current and future  private  and  public  sector  investment. ADB  is 
the  largest  provider  of  renewable  energy  assistance  to  the  country  under  its 
Renewable  Energy  Development  Sector  Investment  Program.10 Support  to  the 
projects  will  directly  build  on  and  complement  extensive  work  under  the 
investment program in promoting renewable energy in Pakistan. 
The  proposed  PCG  structure  allows  ADB  to  participate  in  a  fully  Shariah-
compliant financing structure, which would not have been possible if ADB merely 
provided  a  loan.  This  allows  ADB  to  be  more  responsive  to  borrower 
requirements  and  provides  potential  for  expanding  financing  opportunities  in 
developing  member  countries.  The  proposed  PCG  structure  has  been  made 
possible  because  of  close  cooperation  between  ADB  and  IDB.  This  will 
strengthen  ADB’s  relationship  with  IDB,  which  is  one  of  its  key  development

A. 

Safeguard and Social Dimensions  

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

19. 
In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is environment 
category  B,  involuntary  resettlement  category  C,  and  indigenous  peoples  category  C.  The 
environmental assessment was carried out in line with national laws and regulations and ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. The Environmental Protection Agency of the Government of Sindh 
has  issued  the  necessary  environmental  permits  for  the  projects.  The  project  sites  and  their 
immediate  environs  do not support  natural  vegetation  of  any  ecological significance. The  sites 
do  not  provide  habitat  to  any  terrestrial,  avian,  or  aquatic faunal  species,  nor  are they  located 
along the route of migratory birds. No settlement exists at the proposed sites or their immediate 
vicinities,  nor  is  any  economic  activity  such  as  cultivation  carried  out  there.  During  operation, 
local  communities  will  not  be  affected  as  they  are  located  several  kilometers  away  from  the 
project sites. The potential environmental and social impacts and risks of the project have been 
identified,  and  effective  measures  to  avoid,  minimize,  mitigate,  and  compensate  for  adverse 
impacts  are  incorporated  in  environmental  management  plans.  A  dedicated  environment, 
health, and safety officer will be appointed in FWE I and FWE II to manage the projects’ social 
and  environmental  health  and  safety  risks  and  will  be  supported  by  appropriate  budget  for 
mitigation  measures.11 The  borrowers  will  be  required  to  comply  with  ADB’s  Social  Protection 
Strategy12 and report to ADB  on  their  compliance  and the  compliance  of contractors  with  core 
labor standards.13 Information disclosure and consultations with affected people are conducted 
in accordance with ADB requirements. 
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy  

20. 
The borrowers have been advised of ADB’s standardized approach to anticorruption and 
its  policy  of  implementing  best  international  practice  relating  to  the  combating  of  money 
laundering  and  the  financing  of  terrorism.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  project  documentation 
includes  appropriate  anticorruption  provisions  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance.
